definitions: make a small cut or notch in a surface accidentally or deliberately
take something without permission often in a sneaky or casual way
examples: He nicked his chin while shaving this morning
The knife nicked the edge of the wooden table
Someone nicked my bike from outside the store
The kids nicked some cookies from the kitchen jar

definitions: cover the surface of something with a thin layer of nickel metal
examples: The factory nickels the metal parts to prevent rust
They decided to nickel the bathroom fixtures for durability

definitions: give someone or something a casual name different from their real name
examples: His friends nicknamed him Buddy because of his friendliness
The students nicknamed their strict teacher The Dragon

definitions: pinch bite or squeeze something sharply between two surfaces or with teeth
go somewhere quickly for a short time usually to do something specific
examples: The puppy playfully nipped at my fingers
The cold wind nipped at our exposed skin
I'll just nip to the store for some milk
She nipped out during her lunch break

definitions: reject cancel or put an end to something often a plan or idea
examples: The boss nixed our proposal for a new project
Bad weather nixed our plans for a picnic

definitions: tie or arrange rope into a loop that tightens when pulled
examples: The cowboy noosed the rope to catch the calf
He carefully noosed the climbing rope around the tree

definitions: make something conform to a normal or standard condition pattern or level
examples: The new policy aims to normalize working from home
They need to normalize the data before analyzing it

definitions: cut a v-shaped indentation or groove into an edge or surface
achieve or record something especially a victory or successful result
examples: He notched the stick to mark each day
The carpenter notched the beams to fit together
The team notched another victory in the tournament
She notched up her third promotion this year

definitions: formally or officially inform someone about something important or required
examples: The school will notify parents about the schedule change
Please notify the manager if you'll be absent

definitions: provide food or substances necessary for growth health and good condition
help develop or grow something by providing support care or encouragement
examples: A balanced diet nourishes your body with essential vitamins
The soil nourishes the plants with important minerals
Good teachers nourish their students' love of learning
Reading nourishes the mind and expands our thinking

definitions: push someone or something gently with your elbow hand or body
gently encourage or persuade someone to do something without being forceful
examples: She nudged him awake during the boring lecture
The cat nudged my hand wanting to be petted
His parents nudged him toward a career in medicine
The advertisement nudges consumers to buy organic products

definitions: heat food quickly in a microwave oven usually informally or carelessly
attack or destroy something with nuclear weapons or overwhelming force
examples: Just nuke the leftovers for two minutes
I nuked some popcorn for the movie
The movie showed aliens threatening to nuke Earth
The general wanted to nuke the enemy base

definitions: make something legally invalid or without legal force especially a contract
make something ineffective or cancel out its force value or effect
examples: The court decided to nullify the unfair contract
The judge nullified the jury's verdict due to misconduct
His mistakes nullified all his hard work
The penalty nullified their goal in the match

definitions: make a part of the body unable to feel anything through cold drugs or shock
make someone unable to feel emotions or think clearly due to shock
examples: The dentist will numb your mouth before the procedure
The cold water numbed my fingers within minutes
The tragic news numbed everyone in the community
Years of disappointment had numbed him to rejection

definitions: care for and encourage the growth or development of someone or something
help a feeling idea or belief to develop and grow stronger over time
examples: Parents nurture their children with love and attention
The gardener carefully nurtured the delicate seedlings
The company nurtures talent through mentorship programs
She nurtured her passion for art throughout college

definitions: do what someone in authority tells you to do or follow established rules
examples: Children should obey their parents and teachers
All drivers must obey the traffic laws

definitions: bind or compel someone legally or morally to do something specific
examples: The contract obligates him to work for two years
Parents are obligated to provide for their children

definitions: do something as a favor or service to help someone who asks
bind someone legally or morally to do something making it necessary
examples: She obliged by lending me her car
The waiter obliged with extra napkins
The law obliges employers to provide safe workplaces
Honor obliges him to keep his promise

definitions: destroy utterly so that nothing remains visible or able to be recognized
remove all signs traces or memories of something from existence
examples: The explosion obliterated the abandoned building
The storm obliterated all traces of their campsite
Time had obliterated his memories of childhood
The new highway will obliterate the historic neighborhood

definitions: make something difficult to understand see or discover by making it unclear
keep from being seen clearly by covering blocking or making dark
examples: Technical jargon obscures the meaning of the document
His emotions obscured his judgment in the situation
Clouds obscured the mountain peak from view
The tall building obscures our view of the ocean

definitions: block a road path or entrance so that nothing can pass through
prevent or make it difficult for something to happen or make progress
examples: Fallen trees obstructed the mountain road
Please don't obstruct the emergency exits
Bureaucracy often obstructs the legislative process
His stubbornness obstructed negotiations with the union

definitions: act in an official capacity especially at a ceremony sports event or formal occasion
examples: The mayor will officiate at the ribbon cutting ceremony
She officiates basketball games on the weekends

definitions: remove goods or cargo from a ship truck or other vehicle
transfer work responsibility or burden to someone else to reduce your own
examples: Workers offloaded the cargo from the container ship
We need to offload these boxes before closing time
He tried to offload his tasks onto junior staff
The company offloaded its debt to another firm

definitions: counterbalance or compensate for something by having an equal opposite effect
place out of line or at an angle from the usual position
examples: The company offset its carbon emissions by planting trees
Higher sales offset the increased production costs
The architect offset the windows for visual interest
They offset the text to make the design unique

definitions: stare at someone in a way that shows sexual interest or desire
examples: He was caught ogling the models at the fashion show
Stop ogling and focus on your work

definitions: make a sound expressing surprise pleasure excitement or other strong emotion
examples: The crowd oohed at the fireworks display
She oohed over the cute puppies

definitions: flow slowly out of something in a thick sticky way like liquid
display a quality or feeling very strongly and obviously
examples: Honey oozed from the broken jar
Blood oozed from the small cut
He oozes confidence when speaking in public
The old mansion oozes charm and history

definitions: keep someone in subjection and hardship by harsh use of authority or power
examples: The dictator oppressed his people for decades
Throughout history powerful groups have oppressed minorities

definitions: make something as effective perfect or useful as possible by best use of resources
examples: The engineer optimised the design for better performance
We need to optimise our workflow to save time

definitions: make something as effective perfect or useful as possible by best use of resources
examples: The team worked to optimize the website loading speed
She optimized her schedule to be more productive

definitions: arrange or score music for performance by an orchestra
plan organize or arrange something complicated carefully and often secretly
examples: The composer orchestrated the piece for full symphony
He orchestrated the melody for strings and brass
She orchestrated the entire marketing campaign brilliantly
The manager orchestrated a smooth transition

definitions: make someone a priest or minister in a religious ceremony
order or establish something officially especially by law fate or divine will
examples: The bishop will ordain three new priests tomorrow
She was ordained as a minister last year
The constitution ordains equal rights for all citizens
Fate ordained that they would meet again

definitions: arrange things or people in a structured orderly way for efficiency
make arrangements or preparations for an event activity or system
examples: She organised her files by date and topic
The librarian organised books according to subject
They organised a surprise party for their friend
The union organised a strike for better wages

definitions: position something or determine position relative to points of a compass
familiarize someone with new situation surroundings or circumstances
examples: Orient the map so north points upward
The building orients toward the sunrise
The program orients new students to campus life
She needs time to orient herself to the job

definitions: create or initiate something new that hasn't existed before
have a specified beginning source or place where something comes from
examples: She originated the idea for the new product
The artist originated a unique painting technique
The river originates in the mountain springs
This tradition originated centuries ago in Europe

definitions: make something look more attractive by adding decorative items or details
examples: They ornamented the Christmas tree with lights and tinsel
The artist ornamented the frame with gold leaf

definitions: cause a child to become an orphan by death of parents
examples: The war orphaned thousands of innocent children
The accident tragically orphaned the three siblings

definitions: move or swing back and forth in a regular rhythm like a pendulum
vary or fluctuate between different states opinions or conditions repeatedly
examples: The fan oscillates to cool the entire room
The pendulum oscillates with perfect regularity
His mood oscillates between joy and despair
Prices oscillate based on supply and demand

definitions: drive out or expel someone from a position or place especially by force
examples: The board voted to oust the CEO
Rebels attempted to oust the government

definitions: offer more money than someone else for something being sold at auction
examples: A collector outbid us for the rare painting
She outbid several competitors to buy the house

definitions: appear as rock formation at or above the surface of the ground
examples: Granite outcrops along the mountain trail
Ancient rocks outcrop near the riverbed

definitions: express strong disapproval or anger about something publicly and loudly
examples: Citizens will outcry against the unfair tax increase
Environmental groups outcry about pollution levels

definitions: be more successful or perform better than someone else in competition
examples: She always tries to outdo her previous performance
The chef outdid himself with tonight's meal

definitions: move around the side of an enemy position in military tactics
gain advantage over someone by using unexpected clever strategy or tactics
examples: The general planned to outflank the enemy forces
Our troops outflanked them during the night
The company outflanked competitors with innovative marketing
She outflanked her opponent in the debate

definitions: continue to exist or function longer than someone or something else
examples: This battery will outlast cheaper brands
She outlasted all other contestants in the marathon

definitions: officially forbid something by making it against the law
examples: The government voted to outlaw dangerous chemicals
Many countries have outlawed capital punishment

definitions: continue to live after someone else has died or something has ended
examples: She outlived her husband by twenty years
This tradition has outlived its usefulness

definitions: be greater in number than another group or amount
examples: Female students outnumber males at this university
The protesters outnumbered police by ten to one

definitions: perform better or achieve more success than someone or something else
examples: This car outperforms others in its price range
She consistently outperforms her sales targets

definitions: cause someone to feel extremely angry shocked or indignant about something
examples: The unfair verdict outraged the victim's family
His racist comments outraged the entire community
